definitions: causing extreme physical or mental fatigue and requiring much effort
depleting all energy reserves and leaving one completely worn out
examples: The exhausting marathon left runners completely drained
She finished her exhausting twelve-hour work shift
Dealing with his exhausting demands became unbearable
The exhausting negotiations lasted through the night

definitions: examining or treating every detail with complete thoroughness and careful attention
including all possibilities or elements leaving nothing out or unconsidered
examples: The exhaustive investigation examined every possible lead
Scientists conducted exhaustive tests on the samples
The library maintains an exhaustive collection of manuscripts
Her exhaustive list covered every conceivable option

definitions: making one feel very happy, animated, and full of energy or excitement
producing a feeling of physical invigoration and refreshing stimulation
examples: The exhilarating news brought joy to everyone
It was an exhilarating experience meeting her hero
The exhilarating mountain air refreshed the hikers
Swimming in cold water can be exhilarating

definitions: having actual being or existence in the present time or reality
possessing real being as opposed to imaginary or potential existence
examples: The only existent copy resides in the museum
Few existent documents survive from that period
Questions about existent beings fascinate philosophers
The existent universe contains countless mysteries

definitions: relating to existence, especially human existence and its nature or problems
concerned with the philosophy of existentialism and fundamental questions of human meaning
examples: The accident triggered an existential crisis for him
She grappled with existential questions about purpose
Sartre wrote extensively on existential philosophy topics
The play explores existential themes of isolation

definitions: present at the current time and continuing to be so
already established or in place before the present time or situation
examples: The existing system needs major improvements soon
Existing customers receive special discount offers
We must work within existing budget constraints
The existing infrastructure cannot support more traffic

definitions: freed from blame or responsibility after being wrongly accused or suspected
officially declared not guilty or responsible especially by formal legal process
examples: The exonerated prisoner received compensation for wrongful conviction
DNA evidence exonerated suspects after twenty years
The committee exonerated her from all misconduct charges
The investigation exonerated employees of any wrongdoing

definitions: unreasonably high in price or cost beyond what is fair or expected
going far beyond what is reasonable, proper, or moderate in degree
examples: The restaurant charges exorbitant prices for wine
Exorbitant rent forced many businesses to close
He made exorbitant demands on his staff's time
The project required exorbitant amounts of resources

definitions: originating from or characteristic of a distant foreign country or culture
strikingly unusual or strange in appearance or nature attracting interest
examples: The market sells exotic fruits from tropical regions
She collected exotic plants from around the world
Her exotic beauty captivated everyone at the party
He had exotic tastes in music and art

definitions: able to be made larger in size, volume, or scope when needed
designed to increase in capacity or functionality through additions or modifications
examples: The expandable suitcase accommodates extra souvenirs easily
They bought expandable folders for growing files
The expandable memory allows for future storage needs
Our expandable team structure adapts to project demands

definitions: made larger in size, volume, or physical dimensions than before
increased in range, scope, or scale to include more elements
examples: The expanded edition includes three new chapters
They moved into their expanded office space
The expanded program now serves more communities
She presented an expanded version of her theory

definitions: advocating or pursuing territorial expansion especially through military conquest or annexation
supporting policies aimed at economic or organizational growth and increased influence
examples: The expansionist empire conquered neighboring territories relentlessly
Critics denounced the country's expansionist foreign policy
The company pursued an expansionist strategy through acquisitions
His expansionist vision transformed the small business

definitions: covering a wide area in space or scope with considerable extent
open, communicative, and unreserved in manner, speech, or behavior
able to expand or tending to expand in size or volume
examples: The expansive desert stretched endlessly before them
She gestured toward the expansive view
His expansive personality filled the entire room
After dinner, he became expansive about his travels
The expansive clay soil swells when wet
Materials show expansive properties under heat

definitions: having or showing excited anticipation for something about to happen
pregnant and awaiting the birth of a child in the near future
examples: The expectant crowd waited for the announcement
Her expectant face showed hope for good news
Expectant mothers need regular prenatal care visits
The expectant parents decorated the nursery lovingly

definitions: regarded as likely to happen or arrive based on reasonable assumptions
considered normal, usual, or appropriate according to established patterns or standards
examples: The expected delivery date is next Monday
Rain is expected throughout the weekend period
She gave the expected response to his proposal
His behavior followed expected social conventions perfectly

definitions: convenient and practical although possibly improper or immoral in some way
suitable for achieving a particular end especially political advantage regardless of principles
examples: It was expedient to agree rather than argue
The expedient solution ignored long-term consequences
The politician made expedient promises before elections
His expedient decision sacrificed ethics for profit

definitions: sent on or relating to a journey undertaken for a specific purpose
designed or organized for military operations abroad or special missions
examples: The expeditionary team explored uncharted territories carefully
Scientists joined the expeditionary voyage to Antarctica
Expeditionary forces deployed to the conflict zone
The expeditionary unit specialized in rapid deployment

definitions: able to be sacrificed or abandoned to achieve an objective without regret
considered not worth preserving or maintaining due to low value or importance
examples: Military leaders considered certain units expendable
In war, no soldier should be expendable
The company treated temporary workers as expendable
Old equipment became expendable after the upgrade

definitions: costing a lot of money especially more than expected or affordable
demanding great sacrifice or involving serious loss or penalty to obtain
examples: The expensive restaurant exceeded our budget completely
She wore expensive jewelry to the gala
His expensive mistake cost the company millions
Victory came at an expensive price for everyone

definitions: having knowledge or skill from doing something for a considerable time
having undergone or been affected by a particular situation or event
examples: The experienced teacher handled difficult students well
We need experienced professionals for this project
Those who experienced trauma need special support
She experienced discrimination throughout her career

definitions: derived from or based on direct observation or personal experience rather than theory
involving or based on direct participation and hands-on experience in activities
examples: Experiential knowledge comes from direct practice
The course emphasizes experiential learning methods
The museum offers experiential exhibits for children
Experiential therapy helps patients process emotions directly

definitions: based on untested ideas or techniques used in scientific experiments or tests
using or based on new ideas, forms, or techniques not yet established
examples: The experimental drug showed promising early results
Scientists gathered experimental data through controlled tests
The band played experimental music at the festival
Her experimental cooking sometimes produces amazing dishes

definitions: having or showing great knowledge or skill from training and experience
demonstrating the characteristics of someone with specialized knowledge or ability
examples: The expert surgeon completed the delicate operation
She's expert at solving complex mathematical problems
His expert analysis revealed hidden market trends
The expert handling of negotiations impressed everyone

definitions: having passed the date after which something is no longer valid or safe
having come to an end of life or ceased to exist permanently
examples: The expired milk smelled terrible when opened
His expired passport prevented international travel
The expired patient had been dead for hours
Expired hopes gave way to new possibilities

definitions: serving to explain something or make it clearer through description or analysis
intended to provide clarification or additional information about something complex
examples: The explanatory note clarified the complex passage
She added explanatory comments to the document
His explanatory diagram made the concept clearer
The teacher provided explanatory examples for students

definitions: stated clearly and in detail leaving no room for confusion or doubt
describing or showing sexual or violent activity in graphic detail without censorship
examples: The contract contains explicit terms and conditions
She gave explicit instructions for the procedure
The movie received warnings for explicit content
Explicit lyrics require parental advisory labels

definitions: having been blown apart or destroyed by a violent release of energy
shown with parts separated to display internal structure or components clearly
examples: The exploded building left debris everywhere
Investigators examined the exploded device carefully
The exploded diagram shows all component parts
An exploded view helps understand assembly

definitions: unfairly using someone or something for profit or advantage without proper compensation
characterized by taking advantage of vulnerable people or situations for selfish benefit
examples: The exploitative employer paid workers below minimum wage
Critics condemned the exploitative business practices
The exploitative relationship drained her emotionally
Exploitative lending targets desperate borrowers unfairly

definitions: used unfairly for someone else's advantage often involving harm or injustice
made full use of and derived benefit from a resource or situation
examples: The exploited workers organized to demand fair treatment
Exploited children need protection from abuse
They exploited natural resources for maximum profit
She exploited every opportunity for advancement

definitions: done in order to discover or learn more about something not yet understood
serving as a preliminary investigation before more detailed study or action
examples: The exploratory mission mapped uncharted regions
Scientists conducted exploratory research on the phenomenon
The doctor ordered exploratory surgery to diagnose
They held exploratory talks before formal negotiations

definitions: capable of exploding or causing an explosion with violent force
sudden, rapid, and dramatic in increase, development, or effect
likely to become violently angry or lose emotional control quickly
examples: The explosive device was carefully defused by experts
Explosive materials require special handling procedures
The company experienced explosive growth last year
The explosive revelation shocked the entire nation
His explosive temper made colleagues nervous
The meeting turned explosive when accusations flew

definitions: growing or increasing very rapidly at an accelerating rate over time
relating to or denoted by a mathematical exponent or exponential function
examples: The virus spread at an exponential rate worldwide
They experienced exponential growth in user numbers
The exponential function models population growth accurately
Students learned about exponential equations in class

definitions: not covered or hidden and therefore able to be seen clearly
in a vulnerable position without protection from danger or harm
revealed to public knowledge especially something previously hidden or secret
examples: The exposed wiring posed a safety hazard
Her exposed skin burned quickly in the sun
The exposed position left troops vulnerable to attack
Coastal homes are exposed to hurricane damage
The exposed scandal ruined his political career
Exposed secrets destroyed their trusted relationship

definitions: intended to explain or describe something in a clear, detailed way
relating to writing that describes, explains, or provides information about facts
examples: The expository essay explained the scientific process
She excelled at expository writing in college
The teacher assigned expository texts for analysis
His expository style made complex topics accessible

definitions: conveyed or communicated through words, gestures, or other means
shown or manifested clearly through appearance, behavior, or action
extracted or squeezed out from something by applying pressure
examples: Her expressed opinion differed from private thoughts
The expressed wishes of voters guided policy
His expressed anger frightened the children
The disease expressed symptoms after two weeks
Freshly expressed juice tastes better than bottled
The expressed oil retained its natural fragrance

definitions: effectively conveying thought or feeling through words, looks, or gestures
full of expression and meaning, especially in artistic or emotional contexts
examples: Her expressive eyes revealed deep sadness
The actor's expressive face captivated audiences
The dancer's expressive movements told the story
His expressive writing style engaged readers emotionally

definitions: extremely beautiful and delicate showing perfect craftsmanship or natural beauty
intensely felt whether pleasurable or painful to an extreme degree
showing discriminating and refined taste in matters of beauty or style
examples: The exquisite jewelry sparkled in the display
She wore an exquisite silk gown to the ball
He felt exquisite pain from the injury
The music brought exquisite pleasure to listeners
Her exquisite taste showed in every decoration
The restaurant served exquisite French cuisine

definitions: still in existence and not destroyed, lost, or extinct despite age
surviving from an earlier time especially of documents or species
examples: The extant manuscripts date from medieval times
Few extant copies of the book remain
The oldest extant building dates to 1650
Extant species evolved millions of years ago

definitions: able to be made longer or larger in physical dimensions when needed
capable of being prolonged or continued beyond the original time limit
examples: The extendable ladder reached the third floor
They bought an extendable dining table
The extendable deadline gave students more time
Her extendable contract allowed annual renewals

definitions: made longer or larger in physical space or dimensions
lasting longer than usual or expected in duration
expanded to include more people, things, or areas than originally
examples: The extended version includes deleted scenes
They built an extended patio for entertaining
After an extended illness, she returned to work
The extended forecast predicts rain all week
Our extended family gathers every holiday season
The extended warranty covers additional repairs

definitions: designed to be extended or expanded in functionality or capability
capable of being extended in scope, range, or application through additions
examples: The extensible software architecture allows new plugins
They developed an extensible framework for applications
The extensible platform supports custom modules easily
Our extensible design accommodates future growth

definitions: covering or affecting a large area in space or physical extent
large in amount, scale, or scope including many aspects or details
examples: The fire caused extensive damage throughout downtown
The estate includes extensive grounds and gardens
She conducted extensive research for her dissertation
His extensive knowledge impressed the interview panel

definitions: forming, situated on, or relating to the outside or outer surface
relating to the outside appearance or outward manner of something
examples: The exterior walls need fresh paint this spring
Exterior doors must withstand weather conditions
Her calm exterior masked inner turmoil completely
The car's exterior design impressed potential buyers

definitions: relating to Charles Darwin or his theory of evolution by natural selection
characterized by ruthless competition where only the strongest survive and succeed
examples: Darwinian evolution explains species diversity through selection
The museum featured a Darwinian exhibition
The darwinian business environment eliminated weak companies
Office politics created a darwinian corporate culture

definitions: deliberately obscure or ambiguous in meaning like the ancient oracle
relating to prophecy or having prophetic qualities like ancient oracles
examples: His delphic utterances confused everyone present
The CEO gave delphic responses about layoffs
Her delphic warnings proved accurate years later
The delphic prediction unsettled the investors

definitions: relating to or supporting democracy or its principles of government
favoring social equality and representing or appealing to ordinary people
examples: Democratic institutions protect individual rights and freedoms
The country transitioned to democratic governance
The club maintains a democratic atmosphere for members
Her democratic approach welcomed all viewpoints equally

definitions: denoting or relating to the ordinary colloquial form of a language
relating to or used by ordinary common people rather than the elite
examples: The author used demotic language to reach readers
Demotic expressions peppered his academic lectures
The demotic art movement celebrated everyday life
Politicians adopted demotic styles to seem relatable

definitions: relating to sensual pleasure, wild celebration, and uninhibited artistic expression
relating to the Greek god Dionysus or the festivals held in his honor
examples: The party descended into dionysian revelry after midnight
His dionysian lifestyle shocked conservative neighbors
The dionysian festival featured wine and dancing
Ancient dionysian rituals celebrated the harvest

definitions: completely destroyed or eliminated leaving no trace or survivors remaining
killed deliberately and systematically especially referring to genocide or pest control
examples: The invasive species was exterminated from the island
Disease nearly exterminated the native population
The regime exterminated political opponents ruthlessly
Pest control exterminated the termite colony completely

definitions: belonging to or forming the outer surface or structure of something
coming or derived from a source outside the subject or organization
relating to foreign countries or affairs outside one's own nation
examples: External walls provide structural support and insulation
The external appearance seemed perfectly normal
External consultants reviewed the company's operations
External factors influenced the project's success significantly
External trade agreements boosted the economy
The ministry handles external affairs and diplomacy
